While we continue to work on ANJI, Philip and I thought it would be
good to=
 implement another benchmark to ensure code integrity and the
basic functio=
ning of the algorithm.  XOR meets this need somewhat, but
is really too sim=
ple to do anything other than a simple confirmation.

It would be nice to h=
ave a reasonably easy task to code that would
allow comparison between NEAT=
 implementations and other approaches. 
In his 2002 paper, Ken chose pole b=
alancing, specifically double pole
balancing without velocity information, =
and with a punishment for very
fast oscillations.  He showed that NEAT solv=
ed the problem more
quickly than previous approaches.

But in conversations=
 with Colin, he's noted that Ken's solution to
DPNV only required something=
 like 16 connections and 1 hidden node (I
think).  Colin noted that in orde=
r to test phased searching
(alternating complexifying and pruning phases), =
this task was
insufficient, since the population complexity never got high =
enough to
activate the pruning phase.  Is this task almost too easy to real=
ly
use as a reliable benchmark for NEAT?

There have been some variations t=
o pole balancing, but they seem to be
rather ad hoc.  For example:

2D pole=
 balancing -- Allowing the pole to fall in any direction and
allowing the "=
cart" to move in any direction on a 2D plane.  Was used
to test ESP in 1998=
 I think.

Particle Chasing -- Presented in a paper at GECCO this year, inv=
olving
a pole which the neural network can vary the length of at any given
=
time step by extending or retracting, with the goal of getting its tip
as c=
lose as possible to a randomly-moving point hovering above the
cart.

Do pe=
ople on this list see these or other approaches as viable
benchmarks?  Are =
there others in the literature that people know about
that would work bette=
r?

Or do you think DPNV is sufficient as a benchmark?  Could we or should
=
we come up with a more complex control task?  Or a small suite of
easily-im=
plementable benchmarks?

Derek
